title: How have the numbers of health visitors changed?
analysis_commentary:
The government has also made a commitment to increase the numbers of health visiting staff. In the October 2010 spending review, they announced they would recruit an extra 4,200 health visitors by 2015 and, subsequently, there have been various documents that reaffirm the commitment and provide information about how the NHS will be expected to implement the target.

Health visitors support and educate families, from pregnancy through to a child's fifth birthday. Common tasks include: offering parenting support and advice on family health and minor illnesses; new birth visits which include advice on feeding, weaning and dental health; physical and developmental checks, providing families with specific support on subjects such as post-natal depression.

The numbers of health visiting staff have increased from 8,396 in April 2012 to 9,770 in October 2013. This is in line with the governmentâ€™s commitment to increase numbers although it is currently slightly lower than the required levels to meet the commitment by March 2015; an increased rate of recruitment is required between now and then to manage this.
data_source: Health & Social Care Information Centre, Health Visitors Minimum Data Set (HVMDS)
